facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 194 of 1960 filed by special leave from Punjab High Court judgment dated January 20, 1960 in Criminal Revision No. 1485 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 194 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated January 20, 1960, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1485 of 1959.

facts.text: Three appellants convicted by First Class Magistrate of Jullundur under section 167(81) of the Sea Customs Act for acquiring possession of smuggled gold and concealing it.

anchor.surface_text: The three appellants were companyvicted by the First Class Magistrate of Jullundur of an offence under s. 167  81  of the Sea Customs Act for having acquired possession of smuggled gold and for carrying, keeping and companycealing the said gold with intent to defraud the Government knowing that the gold had been smuggled into India from a foreign companyntry and that numberduty had been paid thereon, and were sentenced to terms of imprisonment.

facts.text: Appellants sentenced to terms of imprisonment by Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: and were sentenced to terms of imprisonment.

facts.text: Appeals filed to Sessions Judge, Jullundur; convictions upheld, sentence reduced for third appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals were filed by the accused to the Sessions Judge, Jullundur but the companyvictions were upheld though the sentence was reduced in the case of the third appellant.

facts.text: Revision petition to Punjab High Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: A revision petition preferred therefrom to the High Court of Punjab was dismissed and thereafter the appellants obtained leave from this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution and filed the appeal which is number before us.

facts.text: City Inspector of Police, Jullundur received information about smugglers transporting gold from Amritsar to Jullundur around midnight on July 16, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The City Inspector of Police, Jullundur is stated to have received information that some smugglers were on the point of transporting gold from Amritsar into Jullundur and at about mid-night on July 16, 1958,

facts.text: Further information received that some smugglers were in the house of Gian Chand, the first appellant.

anchor.surface_text: further information that some of these had actually companye and were present in the house of Gian Chand-the first appellant.

facts.text: Raid party organized and house of first appellant raided at about 3 A.M. on July 17, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: A raid-party was accordingly orgainsed and the house of the first appellant was companydoned and raided at about 3 A.M. on the early morning of July 17,1958.

facts.text: Gold bars found on persons of inmates and in the house, along with large amount of cash.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of the search certain bars of gold were found on the person of some of the inmates of the house and in the house itself, as also a large amount of cash.

facts.text: First appellant (Gian Chand), his wife (third appellant), and her brother (second appellant) arrested.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the first appellant, his wife-the third appellant-and her brother-the second appellant-were arrested, the gold found was seized and a companyplaint filed charging the three accused of offences under ss. 411 and 414 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Gold seized and complaint filed under sections 411 and 414 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: the gold found was seized and a companyplaint filed charging the three accused of offences under ss. 411 and 414 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: IPC case not proceeded with; Police report on January 7, 1959 that no case made out, case dropped.

anchor.surface_text: This charge of receiving stolen property preferred against the three appellants was, however, number proceeded with and the Police Inspector made a report to the Court on January 7, 1959, that numbercase had been made out against them, and the case was thereupon dropped.

facts.text: Assistant Collector of Customs applied to Magistrate for delivery of gold bars under s.180 Sea Customs Act; delivered on January 7, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, the Assistant Collector of Customs companytacted the City Police at Jullundur and made an application to the Court of the First Class Magistrate, Jullundur for the delivery of these gold-bars to the Customs authorities obviously under s. 180 of the Sea Customs Act to the terms of which we shall refer later, and they were delivered to the Customs authorities on January 7, 1959,

facts.text: Notice issued to appellants to show cause why gold should not be confiscated under s.167(8) Sea Customs Act.

anchor.surface_text: Very soon thereafter a numberice was issued to the appellants to show cause why the gold in the possession of the Customs authorities should number companyfiscated under s. 167  8  of the Sea Customs Act,

facts.text: Collector passed order confiscating the gold; order final.

anchor.surface_text: and after companysidering the explanations of the appellants the Collector passed an order directing the companyfiscation of the gold. That order has become final and this appeal is number companycerned with the companyrectness of the order of companyfiscation of the gold under s. 167  8 .

facts.text: Sanction accorded to prosecute appellants under s.167(81) Sea Customs Act during confiscation proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: During the proceedings before the Customs authorities for companyfiscation, sanction was accorded to prosecute the appellants for an offence under s. 167  81  which runs in these terms

facts.text: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947 enacted and came into force on March 25, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947, was enacted which came into force on March 25, 1947.

facts.text: Notification issued on March 25, 1947 under s.8(1) FERA banning import of gold without Reserve Bank permission.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day on which the Act came into force a numberification was issued under this section reading Restrictions on import of gold and silver.- In exercise of the powers companyferred by sub-s. 1 of s. 8 of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947  Act 7 of 1947  and in supersession of the numberification of the Government of India in the late Finance Department No. 12  11  FI/47, dated the 25th March, 1947,

facts.text: First Class Magistrate held s.178A Sea Customs Act applicable, onus on accused.

anchor.surface_text: Without much of a discussion or a companysideration of the several provisions the learned First Class Magistrate held that s. 178 A of the Sea Customs Act was applicable to the case and that accordingly the onus was properly on the accused.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held s.178A applicable but alternatively found prosecution positively proved gold smuggled and accused acts.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter was before the learned Sessions Judge he first held that s. 178A of the Customs Act did apply to the case before him but proceeded also to deal with the case on an alternative footing that the provisions of s. 178A were number applicable to the case and set out the circumstances which led him to that companyclusion.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dealt with case solely on basis that s.178A applicable.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge who heard the revision in the High Court, however, dealt with the case solely on the footing that s. 178A was applicable.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.178A not applicable as gold not seized under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It would, therefore, follow that, having regard to the circumstances in which the gold came into the possession of the Customs authorities, the terms of s. 178A which requires a seizure under the Act were number satisfied and companysequently that provision cannot be availed of to throw the burden of proving that the gold was number smuggled, on the accused.

arguments.claim: construction of s.178A as per Collector of Customs, Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty

anchor.surface_text: The details of the circumstances in which this provision found its place in the statute book as well as its construction have been dealt with in Collector of Customs, Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty and need not here be repeated.

holdings.text: The terms of s. 178A which requires a seizure under the Act were not satisfied and consequently that provision cannot be availed of to throw the burden of proving that the gold was not smuggled, on the accused.

anchor.surface_text: It would, therefore, follow that, having regard to the circumstances in which the gold came into the possession of the Customs authorities, the terms of s. 178A which requires a seizure under the Act were number satisfied and companysequently that provision cannot be availed of to throw the burden of proving that the gold was number smuggled, on the accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gold seized by police under CrPC, transferred to customs via s.180; no 'seizure under the Act' as required by s.178A(1); distinction between police seizure and customs seizure under s.178; transfer does not create new seizure or shift burden.

holdings.text: A seizure under the Act is one for which the authority to seize is conferred by the Act and in the context it could be referred to as a seizure under s. 178. The seizure from the owner of the property under s. 180 is not a seizure under the Act but by a police officer effecting the seizure under other provisions of the law, for instance the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, it would be seen that these three sections which have to be read together draw a distinction between seizure under the Act and a seizure under provisions of other laws. A seizure under the Act is one for which the authority

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language in ss.178, 180, 178A draws clear distinction between seizures authorized by Sea Customs Act (by customs officers) and those by police under other laws; sections must be read harmoniously.

holdings.text: In the context in which it is used in the Act in s. 178A it means take possession of contrary to the wishes of the owner of the property. No doubt, in cases where a delivery is effected by an owner of the goods in pursuance of a demand under legal right, whether oral or backed by a warrant, it would certainly be a case of seizure but the idea that it is the unilateral act of the person seizing is the very essence of the concept.

anchor.surface_text: This however might be the meaning in particular contexts when used in the sense of the cognate Latin expression Seized while in the context in which it is used in the Act in s. 178A it means take possession of contrary to the wishes

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects broad dictionary meaning of 'seize'; contextual interpretation within Act requires unilateral taking against owner's will, distinguishing voluntary/compliant delivery.

holdings.text: The last part of sub-s. (1) of s. 178A lays the burden of proving that the goods are not smuggled on the person from whose possession the goods are taken. Assuredly when the goods are delivered to the Customs authorities by the Magistrate they are not taken from the possession of the persons accused in criminal case so as to throw the burden of proof on them and it would lead to an absurdity to hold that the section contemplated proof to the contrary by the Magistrate under whose orders the delivery was effected.

anchor.surface_text: The last part of sub-s. (1) of s. 178A lays the burden of proving that the goods are not smuggled on the person from whose possession the goods are taken. Assuredly when the goods are delivered to the Customs authorities by the Magistrate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden shift under s.178A(1) applies to person from whose possession seized; Magistrate's delivery under s.180 cannot trigger burden on accused or absurdly on Magistrate.

holdings.text: A seizure under the authority of law does not involve a deprivation of possession and not merely of custody and so when the police officer seized the goods, the accused lost possession which vested in the police. When that possession is transferred, by virtue of the provisions contained in s. 180 to the Customs authorities, there is no fresh seizure under the Sea Customs Act.

anchor.surface_text: A seizure under the authority of law does not involve a deprivation of possession and not merely of custody and so when the police officer seized the goods, the accused lost possession which vested in the police. When that possession is transferred

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal effect of police seizure vests possession in state/police; s.180 transfer is mere change of custody/possession holder, no new deprivation or seizure under Act.

holdings.text: It is clear that in the absence of any valid statutory provision in that behalf the onus of establishing the two ingredients necessary to bring home the offence to an accused is on the prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that in the absence of any valid statutory provision in that behalf the onus of establishing the two ingredients necessary to bring home the offence to an accused is on the prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.167(81) requires prosecution to prove smuggling and accused's knowing involvement unless statute shifts onus (e.g., s.178A, which does not apply).

holdings.text: If, as we have pointed out earlier, the delivery to the Customs authorities under s. 180 is not a seizure under the Act within s. 178A it would follow that the judgment of the High Court cannot be upheld for it has proceeded on the sole basis of the provisions of that section being attracted.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge who heard the revision in the High Court, however, dealt with the case solely on the footing that s. 178A was applicable. ... it would follow that the judgment of the High Court cannot be upheld for it has proceeded on the sole basis of the provisions of that section being attracted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred by relying exclusively on inapplicable s.178A without considering Sessions Judge's alternative finding on prosecution evidence.

holdings.text: The constitutional validity of that section [s.178A] ... has been decided against the appellants by this Court and is therefore no longer a live issue.

anchor.surface_text: The constitutional validity of that section was challenged before the High Court and figured prominently in the grounds of appeal to this Court but this point has been decided against the appellants by this Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior Supreme Court decision upheld s.178A constitutionality; binds parties.
